west.wegovdemo
Interface TopicOpinionOutput

All Known Implementing Classes:
WegovOutput
public interface TopicOpinionOutput

Output of WeGov topic-opinion analysis. Objects that implement this interface provide a couple of methods for output rendering: most relevant terms per topic, most characteristic documents per topic, document relevance scores and reasons being included into result set.

Author:
sizov

Method Detail

getNumTopics

int getNumTopics()
The number of latent topics used in the analysis model. This parameter is automatically set by topic-opinion analysis based on corpus size and corpus properties.

Returns:
The number K of topics produced by topic-opinion analysis.

getTopicTerms

java.lang.String[] getTopicTerms(int topicID)
The collection of most relevant terms for a given topic. Returns a limited number of most relevant terms for the given topic. The number of characteristic terms is automatically determined by topic-opinion analysis.

Parameters:
topicID - The number of the particular topic of interest, should be between 0..getNumTopics()-1. Otherwise, an empty array will be returned.
Returns:
The array of most relevant terms for a given topic, sorted by topic relevance in descending order.

getTopicTermProbs

double[] getTopicTermProbs(int topicID)
The collection of numeric scores (probabilities) for most relevant terms for a given topic. Returns a limited number of most relevant terms for the given topic. The number of characteristic terms is automatically determined by topic-opinion analysis.

Parameters:
topicID - The number of the particular topic of interest, should be between 0..getNumTopics()-1. Otherwise, an empty array will be returned.
Returns:
The array of most relevant terms for a given topic, sorted by topic relevance in descending order.

getOpinionHistogramLabels

java.lang.String[] getOpinionHistogramLabels()
Returns the list of opinion histogram labels, i.e. labels of intervals used for histogram construction (number of highly relevant documents that show the desired degree of positiveness / negativeness)

Returns:
Labels of the opinion histogram

getOpinionHistogram

int[][] getOpinionHistogram(int topicID)
Returns the opinion histogram for a given topic. The opinion histogram contains - for each label / interval - a list of most relevant documents that have the desired degree of positiveness / negativeness. The corresponding labels for histogram intervals are returned by function getOpinionHistogramLabels.

Parameters:
topicID - - topic for histogram computation
Returns:
Array of arrays, for each histogram element an array of document ids that belong to the topic with high probability and show the desired degree of positiveness / negativeness.

getTopicRelevantDocIDs

int[] getTopicRelevantDocIDs(int topicID)
The collection of labels for most relevant (characteristic) documents in a given topic. In this output, each of the documents is represented by its identifier (label) that was provided to the topic-opinion analysis as part of the input data. The number of characteristic documents for the given topic is automatically determined by topic-opinion analysis.

Parameters:
topicID - The number of the particular topic of interest, should be between 0..getNumTopics()-1. Otherwise, an empty array will be returned.
Returns:
The array of IDs (labels) for documents that appear to be most relevant with respect to the given topic.

getTopicRelevantDocScores

double[] getTopicRelevantDocScores(int topicID)
The collection of scores for most relevant (characteristic) documents in a given topic. In this output, each of the documents is characterized by its relevance score. The scores appear exactly in the same order and quantity as topic-specific document IDs returned by getTopicRelevantDocIDs().

Parameters:
topicID - The number of the particular topic of interest, should be between 0..getNumTopics()-1. Otherwise, an empty array will be returned.
Returns:
The array of document scores for documents that appear to be most relevant with respect to the given topic. The scores appear exactly in same order as document IDs returned for same topic by getTopicRelevantDocIDs().

getTopicOpinionDocIDs

int[] getTopicOpinionDocIDs(int topicID)
The collection of labels for documents in a given topic that represent key opinions. In this output, each of the documents is represented by its identifier (label) that was provided to the topic-opinion analysis as part of the input data. The number of characteristic documents for the given topic is automatically determined by topic-opinion analysis.

Parameters:
topicID - The number of the particular topic of interest, should be between 0..getNumTopics()-1. Otherwise, an empty array will be returned.
Returns:
The array of IDs (labels) for documents that appear to be most relevant with respect to the given topic.

getTopicOpinionDocScores

double[] getTopicOpinionDocScores(int topicID)
The collection of scores for documents in a given topic that represent key opinions. In this output, each of the documents is characterized by its score that represents opinion strongness. The scores appear exactly in the same order and quantity as topic-specific document IDs returned by getTopicOpinionDocIDs().

Parameters:
topicID - The number of the particular topic of interest, should be between 0..getNumTopics()-1. Otherwise, an empty array will be returned.
Returns:
The array of document scores for documents that appear to be most relevant with respect to the given topic. The scores appear exactly in same order as document IDs returned for same topic by getTopicOpinionDocIDs().

getTopicOpinionDocReasons

java.lang.String[] getTopicOpinionDocReasons(int topicID)
The collection of reasons for documents in a given topic that represent key opinions. In this output, each of the documents is characterized by its reason being in the result set. The set of reasons includes relevance and strongness of several affective aspects (agreement, positiveness, etc.). Reasons appear exactly in the same order and quantity as topic-specific document IDs returned by getTopicOpinionDocScores().

Parameters:
topicID - The number of the particular topic of interest, should be between 0..getNumTopics()-1. Otherwise, an empty array will be returned.
Returns:
The array of explanations why particular documents appear to be most relevant with respect to the given topic. The reasons appear exactly in same order as document IDs returned for same topic by getTopicOpinionDocScores().

getDocumentBody

java.lang.String getDocumentBody(int docID)
The source of one document from the input collection. The order of postings is exactly the same in input array, provided by TopicOpinionInput.

Parameters:
docID - - document ID as position of the document in the array.
Returns:
the body of requested document.

getUser

java.lang.String getUser(int docID)
User name for a given document ID.

Parameters:
docID - - document ID as position of the document in the array.
Returns:
the user of requested document.

getTopicUsers

java.lang.String[] getTopicUsers(int topicID)
The collection of usernames for most relevant users regarding a given topic.

Parameters:
topicID - The number of the particular topic of interest, should be between 0..getNumTopics()-1. Otherwise, an empty array will be returned.
Returns:
The array of IDs (labels) for users that appear to be most important with respect to the given topic.

getAllDocuments

java.util.Collection getAllDocuments()
Returns all analyzed documents along with estimated topic scores for each topic, all opinion weights together with opinion names. Can be used to construct more comprehensive result sets of your choice (than top-X as supported by other functions).

Returns:
A collection of simple object containers (wegov.TopicOpinionDocument) that contain desired information per document.
See Also:
TopicOpinionDocument

getValence

double getValence(int topicID)
Returns The overall positiveness/negativeness of a topic.

Parameters:
topicID - - the ID of the desired topic, value between 0 and TopicOpinionOutput.getNumTopics()-1.
Returns:
The valence value on the scale between -10 (very negative) and +10 (very positive).

getControversity

double getControversity(int topicID)
Returns The overall controversity of a topic.

Parameters:
topicID - - the ID of the desired topic, value between 0 and TopicOpinionOutput.getNumTopics()-1.
Returns:
The controversity value, computed as normalized variance over individual document specific valence scores (which all are on the scale between -10..+10).

getTopicTermScores

double[] getTopicTermScores(int topicID)
Returns Returns a vector of term (word) probabilities for a given topic. This output is used to estimate similarity between topics. Returned values for two topics are always exactly in the same order of terms. The actual terms (strings) are not part of the output.

Parameters:
topicID - - the ID of the desired topic, value between 0 and TopicOpinionOutput.getNumTopics()-1.
Returns:
The array of values that are interpreted as term probabilities for a given topic. Notably, the values form a multinomial distribution and thus sum up to 1. For any two topics, values in corresponding arrays are for exactly the same sequence of terms.

topicDist

double topicDist(int topicID1,
                 int topicID2)
Estimates the distance between two topics in the space of term distribution vectors, using Jensen-Shannon divergence as a distance measure. From the conceptual perspective, the JS divergence can be seen as a smoothed and symmetrized relative entropy between two distributions. This means, two identical distributions have zero divergence, and two distributions that have no terms in common have max divergence. The implementation uses the log2 variation of JS divergence and returns values in the interval [0..1]: 0 corresponds to zero self-distance, and 1 is the max possible distance. The JS divergence is symmetric (i.e. dist(a,b) = dist(b,a)).

Parameters:
topicID1: - the ID of the first topic, value between 0 and TopicOpinionOutput.getNumTopics()-1.
topicID2: - the ID of the second topic, value between 0 and TopicOpinionOutput.getNumTopics()-1.
Returns:
Distribution-based distance between two topics in the range [0..1], with 0 corresponding to zero self-distance and 1 the max possible distance between two "orthogonal" topics.
